contentrichtext.text: {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image=[[Image:HMSgib.jpg|300px|]] |Ship caption=HMS ''Gibraltar'' }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag=[[Image:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|Royal Navy Ensign]] |Ship class= |Ship name=HMS ''Gibraltar'' |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder=Napier, [[Glasgow]] |Ship laid down=2 December 1889 |Ship launched=27 April 1892 |Ship christened= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified=Depot ship 1914 |Ship refit= |Ship captured= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate=Sold for breaking up September 1923 |Ship status= |Ship homeport= }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship displacement=7,770 tons |Ship length={{convert|387.5|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|60|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|24|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship propulsion=2 shafts, 12,000hp |Ship speed={{convert|20|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} |Ship range=10,000 nautical miles (19,000 km) at 10 knots (19 km/h) |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity= |Ship complement=544 |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=2 x [[BL 9.2 inch gun Mk III - VII|BL {{convert|9.2|in|mm|sing=on|sigfig=4}} Mk VI guns]]<br> 10 x [[QF 6 inch Mk I - III naval gun|QF {{convert|6|in|mm|sing=on|sigfig=4}} guns]]<br> 12 x 6pdr guns<br> 4 x 14in torpedo tubes |Ship armour=Steel:<br>3" to 5" decks<br>6" casemates<br>3" 9.2" gun shields<br>2" to 7" ammunition hoists<br>12" conning tower |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship notes= }} |} {{otherships|HMS Gibraltar}} '''HMS ''Gibraltar''''', was an [[Edgar class cruiser|''Edgar'' class]] [[cruiser]] launched in 1892 for service in the [[Royal Navy]]. She was built and engineered by Messrs Napier of [[Glasgow]]. Of 7,700 loaded displacement, she was coal-fired with four double-ended cylindrical boilers driving two shafts. She could make {{convert|20|kn|km/h}} with forced draught and {{convert|18|kn|km/h}} with natural draught. She was a very good sea boat and an exceptional steamer. During her early career she served mainly on foreign stations. In late 1899 she had a complete refit at [[HMNB Portsmouth|Portsmouth dockyard]].<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence |day_of_week=Monday |date=1 January 1900 |page_number=7 |issue=36027| }}</ref> In March 1901 she was commissioned by Captain A. H. Limpus, with a complement of 544 officers and men, to take the place as [[flagship]] of [[Arthur Moore (Royal Navy officer)|Rear-Admiral Arthur Moore]], who had been appointed [[Cape of Good Hope Station|Commander-in-Chief on the Cape Station]].<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=6 March 1901 |page_number=10 |issue=36395| }}</ref> Despite her obsolescence, she saw service in World War I, first with the 10th Cruiser Squadron on Northern Patrol and from 1915 as a depot ship for this group, based in the [[Shetland Islands]]. Future [[First Sea Lord]] [[John H. D. Cunningham]] served aboard her as a midshipman. Captain [[Ronald Arthur Hopwood]], R.N. was in command 1913â€“1914, leaving at the start of [[World War I]]. ''Gibraltar'' was sold in 1923. ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Colledge}} * Roger Chesneau and Eugene M. Kolesnik, ed., ''Conway's All The Worlds Fighting Ships, 1860-1905'', (Conway Maritime Press, London, 1979), ISBN 0-85177-133-5 {{Edgar class cruiser}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gibraltar (1892)}} [[Category:Edgar-class cruisers]] [[Category:Clyde-built ships]] [[Category:Victorian-era cruisers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:World War I cruisers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1892 ships]]
